thread.title: Accredited Bodies set for windfall after agreement to halve APC
thread.title_full: Accredited Bodies set for windfall after agreement to halve APC

title: Accredited Bodies set for windfall after agreement to halve APC
text:
Save 
Companies including Hays Travel and The Global Travel Group, are set to be handed back hundreds of thousands of pounds after the CAA and Air Travel Trust (ATT) agreed to halve the Atol Protection Contribution (APC) from £2.50 to £1.25. 
TTG understands that the cut will be backdated to May 1 2014, meaning that each firm is in line for a substantial lump sum payment. 
Accredited Bodies will continue to pay the £2.50 charge upfront but every quarter will then invoice the ATT for £1.25 
The cut is also set to benefit HM Revenue and Customs, which will subtract VAT (currently at 20%) from the £1.25, meaning the Accredited Bodies will only actually receive around £1.04. 
The Air Travel Trust Fund, which covers company failures, currently has a surplus of around £94 million after a period of relatively few failures. 
Head of Atol, Andy Cohen, said: “Trust accounts have bought a much greater degree of resilience into the financial protection structure, which is good news for both Accredited Body members and their customers, the holidaymakers. 
“The new arrangements also mean that the failure of an Accredited Body has significantly reduced the impact on the Air Travel Trust’s funds. 
“Furthermore, in setting up the accounts, we do recognise this has represented a significant cost to the Accredited Bodies. 
“As a result, the trustees of the ATT have considered how it should recognise this increased resilience, and has decided to pay an [Accredited Body] a service charge of £1.25 for each ATOL booking taken.” 
The Accredited Body system came into being in 2012 following the changes to the Atol regulations. 
The move meant that the likes of Travel Counsellors and Advantage took on the risk associated with company failures, which had formerly been with the ATT. 
The CAA then imposed a deadline of May 1 2014 for all Accredited Bodies to move to trust accounts. 
Trust accounts are designed to ensure all funds are ring-fenced in the event of a company collapse. 
The change took a lot of the risk away from the CAA and moved it to the Accredited Bodies. 
Speaking earlier this year, the CAA’s David Moesli said that any cut to the APC was unlikely before 2017. 
The CAA’s Accredited Bodies are: Advantage Travel Centres Ltd, Barrhead Travel Service Ltd, Broadway Travel Services (Wimbledon) Ltd, The Freedom Travel Group Ltd, Global Travel Group Ltd, Hays Travel Ltd, The Midcounties Co-operative Ltd and Travel Counsellors Ltd. 
More than 1,300 UK travel firms are now members of the eight CAA licensed Accredited Bodies.
